newsitem.title: INDIA: Seven rebels, one soldier killed in India clashes.
newsitem.headline: Seven rebels, one soldier killed in India clashes.

text.p: Soldiers killed at least seven separatist militants in two clashes in northeast India, and insurgents killed one paramilitary soldier in a third attack, police and army officials said on Friday.
Four tribal guerrillas of the National Socialist Council of Nagaland were killed by soldiers at Mokokchung town in the mountainous state of Nagaland near the Burmese border, authorities said.
Troops killed at least three insurgents, including a woman, of the United Liberation Front of Asom (ULFA) in Borthekerabari village in the tea- and oil-rich state of Assam.
Soldiers recovered large quantities of arms and explosives in both incidents, which occurred on Thursday, officials said.
In a separate attack by insurgents on a paramilitary camp, separatist guerrillas killed one soldier and wounded six, four of them seriously, authorities said.
They said rebels belonging to the separatist United National Liberation Front (UNLF) opened fire on the camp late on Thursday in the heavily wooded state of Manipur, which borders Burma.
It was the UNLF's second major attack on a paramilitary camp in the past week. The rebels killed seven soldiers on Monday.
India's northeastern region, comprising seven states with more than 200 ethnic groups and rich in minerals and timber, has been racked by separatist violence for decades.
The region is surrounded by Burma, Bangladesh, Bhutan and China, and linked to the rest of India by a 20-km (12-mile) wide corridor in the eastern state of West Bengal.

Political parties led by Assam's ruling Asom Gana Parishad launched a 10-hour general strike on Friday to protest against an attempt by militants last Sunday to kill the chief minister, Prafulla Kumar Mahanta.
Suspected ULFA guerrillas set off a bomb on a road minutes after Mahanta's vehicle had passed by.
"There is total response to the strike," a senior government official in the Assam capital Guwahati said. "All business establishments are closed and vehicles are off the road all over the state."
